bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, December 31, 1924

div1.p: Connor discusses his yellow fever campaign in El Salvador; as well as the work of his colleagues in Honduras, Nicaragua and Guatemala.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, December 31, 1924
div1.opener:

6a. SECCION DE LA
DIRECCION GENERAL DE SANIDAD:
Sub-Sección Especial de Lucha
y Control Contra el
AEDES AEGYPTI
-----
REP. DE EL SALVADOR
C. A.
----
San Salvador,
December 31, 1924
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
The Home Office cables that you do not endorse the Internittant
Plan of Control in reducing the aedes aegypti in Salvador nor leaving this
country for Guatamala.

I do not think that I have ever discussed with you this
plan of control probably because I had never before found a place in
which it was applicable and my motive here primarily was to increase
efficiency rather than economy. The results obtained to date indicate in
no uncertain terms that it can be safely apllied in Salvador.

Since your last visit to this coast. Salvador, more than any other
Central American , has advanced remarkably in road construction and in ex-
tending her railroads until now one can journey east and west the entire
length of the Republic c and by good dirt roads every village can be easily
reached from the Capital or the nearest railroad station in one or two
days. The railroads touch nearly all our key positions, only Gotera and
Chalatenango being off the usual line of travel. I am calling these cities
key positions for the time until our survey of the areas are complete, the
history of the regions of which these cities are capitals is that they only
people
contract yellow fever when they come to San Salvador.

Salvador as you probably know is quite unlike other
Latin Republics in that it is a better organized and the people respond
more readily to the mandates of the Government. Many communities derive
their water supply from streams which have been dammed and the water is
carried to the community by underground pipes with taps located at convienent
places or else it has been arranged to empty into a public place and to this
the people come daily for the domestic supply. The barrel is not in general
use in the interior towns and not very popular in the cities either. By
far the most used water receptacle in the home is the cantaroj or olla
and this is not of large size either as compared with similiar receeptacles
found in Mexico and Ecuador. In the indian home one rarely finds more than
one olla and away from the cities the indian homes predominate.

In the large cities we have to contend with the indoor
pila but very few tanks and these only in the homes of the well-to-do,
the poorer people here also resort to the cantaro or olla, again we have no
haciendas comparable with those of Yucatan either in size or number of
people maintained. Salvador is a country of urban population and governed
directly by the officials and not by the ‘haciendado’ which explains why we
are able to secure almost complete co-operation by having local officals
issuing proclamations. The failure to comply with the proclamation calls for
a small fine which is increased in the case of refractory persons. Again
Salvador is unlike other latin countries in that a fine imposed is collected
from the highest to the lowest citizen, of course, great care is being ex-
ercised to see that the system is not abused but I must confess that it had
seemed feasible to me to conduct a campaign with a system of fines as an
ally until I came to Salvador here it is an undoubted success.

In the early weeks of the present campaign I stationed men at
all key positions which appeared to me to be favorable for the propogation of
yellow fever and which gave a history of having had the infection in recent
years i.e. San Salvador, Sonsonate, Santa Ana, Ahuachapan, Atquizaya,, the ports,

REP. DE EL SALVADOR
C. A.

Cojutepeque, San Vicente, Zacataxoluca, Usulutan, San Miguel, then
the twenty or more towns which feed directly into San Salvador. In addition
to the foregoing I started men into the interior towns to make mosquito sur-
verys as I could find no record of this having been done before as only in
this way could I know what the exact condition of affairs was.

As the mosquito survey advanced it became apparent that the small
interior towns were not a factor, as, in many instances, no aedes aegypti
could be found therein, in the larger communities but below the rank of a
city it was noted that the permanent aedes aegypti breeding place was the
public pila and this is especially true of the towns near the Capital and
the emptying and scrubbing the interior of the pila has nearly extinguished
the specie. It is fair to assume in these instances that the people were
carrying larvae from the pila to their homes hwere many bred out but fortu-
nately the vast majority of homes do not possess more than one water contain-
er therefore it quite out of the question for the mosquito to establish a perm
anent breeding place in such homes except the chance of forgotten vase, etc.
and here the doctrine of chances operates against it becoming permanent.
Salvador is essentially a country of people who just enough to continue from
day to day but are seemingly unable to accumulate. And this factor works in
our favor.

You will see that our problem is narrowing down to the cities and
here again the old story of permanence attracts the aedes aegypti. In the
established homes and by this I mean homes of the well-to-do, the water will
be conserved in large containers such as the tank, pilas and the flower
garden will have from ten to one hundred antguards protecting the flower trees
and all of these ant guards were breeder until an order was inssued requiring
their destruction. The fringe of the city is mosquito infested but does not
have the permanence of the central area and can usually be eliminated for re-
gular inspection after thwo or three vueltas. It may seem strange that barrels
are not in use here but the fact remains that they are not popular possibly
because they cost money and this the average Salvadorean does not have and
possibly because the cantaro holding from one to five gallons answer their
needs.

As stated earlier in this letter the first motive for adopting the
intermittant control plan was to increase effciency at the same time it was
obvious that if successful economies would be effected. With the permanent
brigadas the results were not satisfactory as the native is unable to work
well unless closely supvervised and this meant a larger foreign personel, and
I was not planning for this unless it was absolutely necessary. There are
good reasons for keeping our foreign staff at a minimum. I had used Brigadas
Volantes in Ecuador and decided to try them here. Our house index in the
Capital was down to less than 2% and the key positions to nearly 5% and we were
at the begining of the dry season and it appeared to me that here was the
place and the time to try out again the brigadas volantes.

I was perhaps influenced in part by the observation that the Salvado-
reans are a high strung independent people who like many latins are inclined
to find fault with the firemen after the fire has been smothered and so it
is in the present campaign, the weekly visits had begun to annoy the people
altho I have no doubt but that they could have been continued but the ten-
dency would have been for the snnoyance to increase until the Government had
been appealed and the most probable results would have been an order to stop
the visits, At first thought it may seems that this is far fetched but the
facts are that this Government still maintains that there was no yellow fever
in the country, “only a few suspicious cases”. The physycology which prompts an
individual to announce the elimination of an infection which he will not admit
as having existed is to my mind one to be anticipated

AEDES AEGYPTI
-----
REP. DE EL SALVADOR
C. A.
----

The report of our last inspection of San Salvador has just come to
my desk and it shows the house index to be 0.41% and this after
and interval of 21 days during which no anti-larvae measures were
applied except for special inspections of places like hotels, pen-
sions, stables soldier barracks, jails and hospitals and
school buildings which places I regard as requiring closer supervision
in Salvador than the home. We stopt inspections in San Salvador
on December 6th, the house index was 0.53%.

If Salvador were a country of tins cans, bottles and barrels, etc.
I doubt if the Internittant control plan would be applicable but I
think that if you could be here at this time that you would agree
to this plan of control for the dry season at least.

From the records that I can gather there the aedes aegypti index
has never been very high, it is estimated that early in this year it
might have been up to 20% house index in the capital and less than
50% in nearby towns that had not been treated in the past two years
or more.

The center of endmicity appears to have been in and around the
capital with temporary centers in Sonsonate, San Miguel and Santa Ana
to which place the infection had been carried at various times by
the soldiers at least we can connect them up with certain outbreaks and
trace the spread to other towns by their movements.
I am quite convinced that the disease has been present here contin-
iously for the last four years, the evidence is not complete but we
are getting at it piecemeal and hope to complete the chain of events
in the very near future.

My gneral plan is to maintain one and possibly two white inspectors
in Salvador and as many native inpsectors as conditions indicate,
the Chief of the Service is Doctor Carlos E. Larde' and he is quite
competent to handle the situation with the two foreign inspectors and
occassional supervision by myself. I will not be away from Salvador
at any time over three weeks and I am quite sure that the work can be
left in their hands for that length of time without slackening.

Mr. Hulse in Honduras is concentrating at Amapala, San Lorenzo and
Nacaome, Molloy in Nicaragua will continue anti-larvae measures during
a part of the coming year at least and Guatamala has indicated its
intention to continue the present campaign. I the Government of Salva-
dor will want to continue the present measures until the end of the
next rainy season.

I will be glad to hear from you and to know your reasons en contra
the internittant control plan.

With very best wishes for the coming year for your-
self and Miss Carter, I am,
